Dialogue: Were you -  Tad.

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: You should go to Mrs. Lincoln. She's in Willie's room.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: She never goes in there.

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: The reception line is already stretching out the door.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I'll be the only man over fifteen and under sixty-five in this whole place not in uniform.

Speaker: tad
Dialogue: I'm under fifteen and I have a uniform.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: My head hurts so.  I prayed for death the night Willie died. The headaches are how I know I didn't get my wish. How to endure the long afternoon and deep into the night.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Trying not to think about him. How will I manage?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Somehow you will.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Somehow. Somehow. Somehow... Every party, every... And now, four years more in this terrible house reproaching us. He was a very sick little boy. We should've cancelled that reception, shouldn't we?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: We didn't know how sick he was.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I knew, I knew, I saw that night he was dying.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Three years ago, the war was going so badly, and we had to put on a face.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But I saw Willie was dying. I saw HIM -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Molly. It's too hard. Too hard.

Speaker: william slade
Dialogue: She's just ten feet yonder. I'd like to keep my job.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Senator Sumner, it has been much too long.

Speaker: charles sumner
Dialogue: "Oh, who can look on that celestial face and -"

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And...?

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: James Ashley, ma'am, we've met several times -

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Praise Heavens, praise Heavens, just when I had abandoned hope of amusement, it's the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee!

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Mrs. Lincoln.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Madame President if you please!  Oh, don't convene another subcommittee to investigate me, sir! I'm teasing! Smile, Senator Wade.

Speaker: bluff wade
Dialogue: I believe I am smiling, Mrs. Lincoln.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'll take your word for that, sir!

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: As long as your household accounts are in order, Madame, we'll have no need to investigate them.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You have always taken such a lively, even prosecutorial interest in my household accounts.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Your household accounts have always been so interesting.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Yes, thank you, it's true, the miracles I have wrought out of fertilizer bills and cutlery invoices. But I had to! Four years ago, when the President and I arrived, this was pure pigsty. Tobacco stains in the turkey carpets. Mushrooms, green as the moon, sprouting from ceilings! And a pauper's pittance allotted for improvements. As if your committee joined with all of Washington awaiting, in what you anticipated would be our comfort in squalor, further proof that my husband and I were prairie primitives, unsuited to the position to which an error of the people, a flaw in the democratic process, had elevated us.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Mother?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: You're creating a bottleneck.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Oh!  Oh, I'm detaining you, and more important, the people behind you! How the people love my husband, they flock to see him, by their thousands on public days! They will never love you the way they love him. How difficult it must be for you to know that. And yet how important to remember it.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Since we have the floor next in the debate, I thought I'd suggest you might...temper your contributions so as not to frighten our conservative friends?

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Ashley insists you're ensuring approval by dispensing patronage to otherwise undeserving Democrats.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I can't ensure a single damn thing if you scare the whole House with talk of land appropriations and revolutionary tribunals and punitive thisses and thats -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: When the war ends, I intend to push for full equality, the Negro vote and much more. Congress shall mandate the seizure of every foot of rebel land and every dollar of their property. We'll use their confiscated wealth to establish hundreds of thousands of free Negro farmers, and at their side soldiers armed to occupy and transform the heritage of traitors. We'll build up a land down there of free men and free women and free children and freedom. The nation needs to know that we have such plans.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: That's the untempered version of reconstruction. It's not... It's not exactly what I intend, but we shall oppose one another in the course of time. Now we're working together, and I'm asking you -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: For patience, I expect.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: When the people disagree, bringing them together requires going slow till they're ready to make up -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Ah, shit on the people and what they want and what they're ready for! I don't give a goddamn about the people and what they want! This is the face of someone who has fought long and hard for the good of the people without caring much for any of `em. And I look a lot worse without the wig. The people elected me! To represent them! To lead them! And I lead! You ought to try it!

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I admire your zeal, Mr. Stevens, and I have tried to profit from the example of it. But if I'd listened to you, I'd've declared every slave free the minute the first shell struck Fort Sumter; then the border states would've gone over to the confederacy, the war would've been lost and the Union along with it, and instead of abolishing slavery, as we hope to do, in two weeks, we'd be watching helpless as infants as it spread from the American South into South America.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Oh, how you have longed to say that to me. You claim you trust them - but you know what the people are. You know that the inner compass that should direct the soul toward justice has ossified in white men and women, north and south, unto utter uselessness through tolerating the evil of slavery. White people cannot bear the thought of sharing this country's infinite abundance with Negroes.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: A compass, I learnt when I was surveying, it'll - it'll point you True North from where you're standing, but it's got no advice

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Robert's going to plead with us to let him enlist.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Make time to talk to Robbie. You only have time for Tad.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Tad's young.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: So's Robert. Too young for the army.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Plenty of boys younger than Robert signing up...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't take Robbie. Don't let me lose my son.

Speaker: john nicolay
Dialogue: Secretary Stanton has sent over to tell you that as of half an hour ago, the shelling of Wilmington harbor has commenced.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: They cannot possibly maintain under this kind of an assault. Terry's got ten thousand men surrounding the Goddamned fort! Why doesn't he answer my cables?

Speaker: welles stanton
Dialogue: The commander is an old goat. I want to hear that Fort Fisher's ours and Wilmington MAJOR ECKERT has fallen! They said -

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: No! No, you're, you're going to tell a story! I don't believe that I can bear to listen to another one of your stories right now!

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: It was right after the Revolution, right after peace had been concluded, and Ethan Allen went to London to help our new country conduct its business with the king. The English sneered at how rough we are, and rude and simple-minded and on like that, everywhere he went, till one day he was invited to the townhouse of a great English lord. Dinner was served, beverages imbibed, time passed, as happens, and Mr. Allen found he needed the

Speaker: charles benjamin
Dialogue: Fort Fisher is ours. We've taken the port.

Speaker: welles
Dialogue: And Wilmington?

Speaker: major eckert
Dialogue: We've taken the fort, but the city of Wilmington has not surrendered.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: How many casualties?

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: Heavy losses.

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: And more to come.

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: Sours the national mood. That might suffice to discourage him -

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: To what? To bring this down? Not in a fight like this. This is to the death.

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: It's gruesome!

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: Are you despairing, or merely lazy? This fight is for The United States of America! Nothing "suffices". A rumor? Nothing! They're not lazy! They're busily buying votes! While we hope to be saved by "the national mood?!"

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: George, please. Stay on course.

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: Bring Stevens to full froth. I can ensure that every newspaperman from Louisville to San Francisco will be here to witness it and print it.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: The floor belongs to the mellifluent gentleman from Kentucky, Mr. George Yeaman.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: I thank you, Speaker Colfax.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Think how splendid if Mr. Yeaman switched.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Too publicly against us. He can't change course now.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: And, and! We will be forced to enfranchise the men of the colored race - it would be inhuman not to! Who among us is prepared to give Negroes the vote?

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: Bless my eyes, if it isn't the Post Master of Millersburg Ohio!

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: Mr. LeClerk felt honor-bound to inform us. Of your disgusting betrayal. Your prostitution.

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: Is that true, Postmaster Hawkins? Is your maidenly virtue for sale?

Speaker: clay hawkins
Dialogue: My neighbors hear that I voted yes for nigger freedom and no to peace, they will kill me.

Speaker: clay hawkins
Dialogue: I want to do right! But I got no courage!!!

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Eleven votes?! Two days ago we had twelve!! What happened?

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: They are ruining us.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Among the few remaining representatives who seem remotely plausible there is a perceptible increase in resistance.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Perhaps you push too hard.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Get back to it, and good day, gentlemen.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: We are at an impasse.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Tell Lincoln to deny the rumors. Publicly.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Tell us what you expect of us.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: I expect you to do your work! And to have sufficient sense and taste not to presume to instruct the President. Or me.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Is there a Confederate offer or not?

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: I suggest you work some changes to your proposal before you give it to the President.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: Did Mr. Lincoln tell you to tell us this, General Grant?

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: It says..."securing peace for our two countries." And it goes on like that.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: I don't know what you -

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: There's just one country. You and I, we're citizens of that country. I'm fighting to protect it from armed rebels. From you.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: But Mr. Blair told us, he, he told President Davis we were -

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: A private citizen like Preston Blair can say what he pleases, since he has no authority over anything. If you want to discuss peace with President Lincoln, consider revisions.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: If we're not to discuss a truce between warring nations, what in heaven's name can we discuss?

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: Terms of surrender.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: "...will have a bad influence. I will be sorry should it prove impossible for you to have an interview with them. I am awaiting your instructions. U.S. Grant, Lieutenant General Commanding Armies United States"

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: After four years of war and near 600,000 lives lost. He believes we can end this war now. My trust in him is marrow deep.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: You could bring the delegates to Washington. In exchange for the South's immediate surrender, we could promise them the amendment's defeat. They'd agree, don't you think? We'd end the war. This week.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Now, here's a sixteen year old boy. They're going to hang him...

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: Ummm... I don't know, sir, I don't know who you're, uh... What time is it?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: It's three forty in the morning.

Speaker: john nicolay
Dialogue: Don't... let him pardon any more deserters...

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: Mr. Stanton thinks you pardon too many. He's generally apoplectic on the subject -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: He oughtn't to have done that, crippled his horse, that was cruel, but you don't just hang a sixteen year old boy for that -

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: Ask the horse what he thinks.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: - for cruelty. There'd be no sixteen year old boys left.  Grant wants me to bring the secesh delegates to Washington.

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: So... There are secesh delegates?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: He was afraid, that's all it was. I don't care to hang a boy for being frightened, either. What good would it do him?

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: Do you need company?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: "Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, City Point. I have read your words with interest."

Speaker: samuel beckwith
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: You think we choose to be born?

Speaker: samuel beckwith
Dialogue: I don't suppose so.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Are we fitted to the times we're born into?

Speaker: samuel beckwith
Dialogue: I don't know about myself. You may be, sir. Fitted.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: What do you reckon?

Speaker: homer bates
Dialogue: I'm an engineer. I reckon there's machinery but no one's done the fitting.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: You're an engineer, you must know Euclid's axioms and common notions.

Speaker: homer bates
Dialogue: I must've in school, but...

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I never had much of schooling, but I read Euclid, in an old book I borrowed. Little enough ever found its way in here -  - but once learnt it stayed learnt.

Speaker: samuel beckwith
Dialogue: "Have Captain Saunders convey the commissioners to me here in Washington."

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: A slight emendation, Sam, if you would.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: The World, the Herald and the Times, New York, Chicago, the Journal of Commerce, even your hometown paper's here.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Say you believe only in legal equality for all races, not racial equality, I beg you, sir. Compromise. Or you risk it all.

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: I've asked you a question, Mr. Stevens, and you must answer me. Do you or do you not hold that the precept that "all men are created equal" is meant literally?

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: The true purpose of the amendment, Mr. Wood, you perfectly-named, brainless, obstructive object?

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: You have always insisted, Mr. Stevens, that Negroes are the same as white men are.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: The true purpose of the amendment -

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: That's not so! You believe that Negroes are entirely equal to white men. You've said it a thousand TIMES -

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: For shame! For shame! Stop prevaricating and answer Representative Wood!

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: He's answered your questions! This amendment has naught to do with race equality!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Who'd ever've guessed that old nightmare capable of such control? He might make a politician someday -

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: I need to go.

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: Your frantic attempt to delude us now is unworthy of a representative. It is, in fact, unworthy of a white man!

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: - stands stinking the moral carcass of the gentleman from Ohio, proof that some men are inferior, endowed by their Maker with dim wits impermeable to reason with cold pallid slime in their veins instead of hot red blood! You are more reptile than man, George, so low and flat that the foot of man is incapable of crushing you!

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: HOW DARE YOU!

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Yet even you, Pendleton, who should have been gibbetted for treason long before today, even worthless unworthy you ought to be treated equally before the law! And so again, sir, and again and again and

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: MR. SPEAKER, WILL YOU PERMIT THIS VILE BOORISH MAN TO SLANDER AND TO THREATEN ME AND -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: I'm sorry you're nauseous, Asa, that must be unpleasant. I want the amendment to pass. So that the Constitution's first and only mention of slavery is its absolute prohibition. For this amendment, for which I have worked all of my life and for which

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I'm not going in.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: You said you wanted to help me.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: This is - This is just a clumsy attempt at discouragement. I've been to army hospitals, I've seen surgeries, I went and visited the malaria barges with mama.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: She told me she didn't take you inside.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I snuck in after - I've seen what it's like. This changes nothing.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: At all rates, I'm happy to have your company.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Morning, Jim.

Speaker: army surgeon
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. President.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Good to see you again.

Speaker: first patient
Dialogue: Hello, sir.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: What's your name, soldier?

Speaker: first patient
Dialogue: Robert.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Robert. Good to meet you, Robert.

Speaker: second patient
Dialogue: Nice to meet you.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: second patient
Dialogue: Kevin.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Tell me your names as I go past. I like to know who I'm talkin' to. Kevin.

Speaker: third patient
Dialogue: Mr. President. John.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: John. I've seen you before.

Speaker: fourth patient
Dialogue: Mr. President...

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I have to do this! And I will do it and I don't need your permission to enlist.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: That same speech has been made by how many sons to how many fathers since the war began? "I don't need your damn permission, you miserable old goat, I'm gonna enlist anyhow!" And what wouldn't those numberless fathers have given to be able to say to their sons - as I now say to mine - "I'm commander-in-chief, so in point of fact, without my permission, you ain't enlisting in nothing, nowhere, young man."

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: It's mama you're scared of, not me getting killed.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: We can't lose you.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: He'll be fine, Molly. City Point's far from the front lines, from the fighting, he'll be an adjutant running messages for General Grant.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: The war will take our son! A sniper, or a shrapnel shell! Or typhus, same as took Willie, it takes hundreds of boys a day! He'll die, uselessly, and how will I ever forgive you? Most men, their firstborn is their favorite, but you, you've always blamed Robert for being born, for trapping you in a marriage that's only ever given you grief and caused you regret!

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: That's not true -

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And if the slaughter of Cold Harbor is on your hands same as Grant, God help us! We'll pay for the oceans of spilled blood you've sanctioned, the uncountable corpses we'll be made to pay with our son's dear BLOOD -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Just, just this once, Mrs. Lincoln, I demand of you to try and take the liberal and not the selfish point of view! You imagine Robert will forgive us if we continue to stifle his very natural ambition?!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And if I refuse to take the high road, if I won't take up the rough old cross, will you threaten me again with the madhouse, as you did when I couldn't stop crying over Willie, when I showed you what heartbreak, real heartbreak looked like, and you hadn't the courage to countenance it, to help me -

Speaker: lincoln mary
Dialogue: That's right. When you I was in the room with refused so much as to comfort Willie, I was holding him in Tad - my arms as he died!

Speaker: lincoln mary
Dialogue: - the child who was not only How dare you! sick, dangerously sick, but beside himself with grief?

Speaker: lincoln mary
Dialogue: Oh but your grief, your How dare you throw that at grief, your inexhaustible me?! grief!

Speaker: lincoln mary
Dialogue: And his mother won't let him I couldn't let Tad in! I near her, `cause she's couldn't risk him seeing how screaming from morning to angry I was! night pacing the corridors, howling at shadows and furniture and ghosts! I ought to have done it, I ought have done for Tad's sake, for everybody's goddamned sake, I should have clapped you in the madhouse!

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I couldn't tolerate you grieving so for Willie because I couldn't permit it in myself, though I wanted to, Mary. I wanted to crawl under the earth, into the vault with his coffin. I still do. Every day I do. Don't... talk to me about grief.  I must make my decisions, Bob must make his, you yours. And bear what we must, hold and carry what we must. What I carry within me - you must allow me to do it, alone as I must. And you alone, Mary, you alone may lighten this burden, or render it intolerable. As you choose.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You think I'm ignorant of what you're up to because you haven't discussed this scheme with me as you ought to have done. When have I ever been so easily bamboozled?  I believe you when you insist that amending the constitution and abolishing slavery will end this war. And since you are sending my son into the war, woe unto you if you fail to pass the amendment.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Seward doesn't want me leaving big muddy footprints all over town.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No one ever lived who knows better than you the proper placement of footfalls on treacherous paths. Seward can't do it. You must. Because if you fail to secure the necessary votes, woe unto you, sir. You will answer to me.

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: I know the vote is only four days away; I know you're concerned. Thank you for your concern over this, and I want you to know: They'll approve it. God will see to it.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I don't envy him his task. He may wish He'd chosen an instrument for His purpose more wieldy than the House of Representatives.

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: Then you'll see to it.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Are you afraid of what lies ahead? For your people? If we succeed?

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: White people don't want us here.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Many don't.

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: What about you?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I...I don't know you, Mrs. Keckley. Any of you. You're ...familiar to me, as all people are. Unaccommodated, poor, bare, forked creatures such as we all are. You have a right to expect what I expect, and likely our expectations are not incomprehensible to each other. I assume I'll get used to you. But what you are to the nation, what'll become of you once slavery's day is done, I don't know.

Speaker: elizabeth keckley
Dialogue: What my people are to be, I can't say. Negroes have been fighting and dying for freedom since the first of us was a slave. I never heard any ask what freedom will bring. Freedom's first. As for me: My son died, fighting for the Union, wearing the Union blue. For freedom he died. I'm his mother. That's what I am to the nation, Mr. Lincoln. What else must I be?

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Oh, it is? What you got goin'?

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Go away!  That watch fob, is that gold?

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Nines paired!

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Gentlemen. You have a visitor.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I wouldn't bet against it, Mr...?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Mr. Bilbo. Gentlemen.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Sir...

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: The Secretary of State here tells me that, uh, you got eleven Democrats in the bag. That's encouraging.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Oh, you've got no cause to be encouraged. Sir. Uh...

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Are we being...fired?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: "We have heard the chimes of midnight, Master Shallow." I'm here to alert you boys that the great day of reckoning is nigh upon us.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: The Democrats we've yet to bag, sir. The patronage jobs simply won't bag `em. They require more...convincing, Mr. President.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Mm-hmm. Do me a favor, willya?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Snagged my eye in the paper this morning. Governor Curtin is set to declare a winner in the disputed Congressional election for the -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: What a joy to be comprehended. Hop on a train to Philadell, call on the Governor -

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Send Latham. Or Schell.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: No, he'll do fine, just polish yourself up first.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: The incumbent is claiming he won it. Name of, uh...

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: That's him.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Coffroth. He is a Democrat.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Pity poor Coffroth.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: It opens!

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Coffroth, Mr. Stevens, Alexander Coffroth, I'm, I'm -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Are we representatives of the same state?

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Y-yes sir! We sit only three desks APART -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: I haven't noticed you. I'm a Republican, and you, Coughdrop, are a Democrat?

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Well, I... Um, that is to say... I -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: The modern travesty of Thomas Jefferson's political organization to which you have attached yourself like a barnacle has the effrontery to call itself The Democratic Party. You are a Dem-o-crat. What's the matter with you? Are you wicked?

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Well, I felt, um, formerly, I -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Never mind, Coffsnot. You were ignominiously trounced at the hustings in November's election by your worthy challenger, a REPUBLICAN -

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: No, sir, I was not, um, trounced! Uh, he wants to steal my seat! I didn't lose the election -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: What difference does it make if you lost or not?! The governor of our state, is...? A Democrat?

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: No, he's a...  A, um, a Ruh...

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Re.

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Re.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Pub.

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Pub.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Li.

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Li.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Can.

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Can. Republican.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: I know what he is. This is a rhetorical exercise. And Congress is controlled by what party? Yours?

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: I know what I must do, sir! I will immediately become a Republican and vote yes for -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: NO! Coffroth will vote yes but Coffroth will remain a Democrat until after he does so.

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: Why wait to switch? I'm happy to SWITCH -

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: We want to show the amendment has bipartisan support, you idiot. Early in the next Congress, when I tell you to do so, you will switch parties. Now congratulations on your victory, and get out.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Now give me the names of whoever else you been hunting.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: George Yeaman.

Speaker: richard schell
Dialogue: Yes. Yeaman.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Y-E-A-M-A-N

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I got it.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Kentucky.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: I can't vote for the amendment, Mr. Lincoln.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I saw a barge once, Mr. Yeaman, filled with colored men in chains, heading down the Mississippi to the New Orleans slave markets. It sickened me, `n more than that, it brought a shadow down, a pall around my eyes.  Slavery troubled me, as long as I can remember, in a way it never troubled my father, though he hated it. In his own fashion. He knew no smallholding dirt farmer could compete with slave plantations. He took us out from Kentucky to get away from `em. He wanted Indiana kept free. He wasn't a kind man, but there was a rough moral urge for fairness, for freedom in him. I learnt that from him, I suppose, if little else from him. We didn't care for one another, Mr. Yeaman.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: I... Well, I'm sorry to hear that -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Lovingkindness, that most ordinary thing, came to me from other sources. I'm grateful for that.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: I hate it, too, sir, slavery, but - but we're entirely unready for emancipation. There's too many QUESTIONS -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: We're unready for peace too, ain't we? When it comes, it'll present us with conundrums and dangers greater than any we've faced during the war, bloody as it's been. We'll have to extemporize and experiment with what it is when it is.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: No, no, but, but, but - But Negroes can't, um, vote, Mr. Lincoln. You're not suggesting that we enfranchise colored people.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I'm asking only that you disenthrall yourself from the slave powers. I'll let you know when there's an offer on my desk for surrender. There's none before us now. What's before us now, that's the vote on the Thirteenth Amendment. It's going to be so very close. You see what you can do.

Speaker: william hutton
Dialogue: I can't make sense of it, what he died for. Mr. Lincoln, I hate them all, I do, all black people. I am a prejudiced man.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I'd change that in you if I could, but that's not why I come. I might be wrong, Mr. Hutton, but I expect... Colored people will most likely be free, and when that's so, it's simple truth that your brother's bravery, and his death, helped make it so. Only you can decide whether that's sense enough for you, or not.

Speaker: preston blair
Dialogue: We've managed our members to a fare- thee-well, you've had no defections from the Republican right to trouble you, whereas as to what you promised - Where the hell are the commissioners?!

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Oh God...  It's true! You, you...lied to me, Mr. Lincoln! You evaded my requests for a denial that, that there is a Confederate peace offer because, because there is one! We are absolutely guaranteed to lose the whole thing -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I can't listen to this anymore! I can't accomplish a goddamned thing of any human meaning or worth until we cure ourselves of slavery and end this pestilential war, and whether any of you or anyone else knows it, I know I need this! This amendment is that cure! We're stepped out upon the world's stage now, now, with the fate of human dignity in our hands! Blood's been spilt to afford us this moment!

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: We need two yeses, three abstentions, or four yeses and one more abstention and the amendment will pass -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: You got a night and a day and a night and several perfectly good hours! Now get the hell out of here and get `em!

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Yes but how?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Buzzards' guts, man.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: Mr. Ashley, the floor is yours.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: On the matter of the joint resolution before us, presenting a Thirteenth Amendment to our national Constitution, which was passed last year by the Senate, and which has been debated now by this estimable body for the past several weeks. Today we will vote...

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: I've just received confirmation of what previously has been merely rumored! Affidavits from loyal citizens recently returned from

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: Are there Confederate commissioners in the Capitol?

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: I don't... I have no idea where they are or if they've arrived or -

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: If they've arrived?!

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: I appeal to my fellow Democrats, to all Republican representatives who give a fig for peace! Postpone this vote until we have answers from the President himself!

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: Postpone the vote!

Speaker: aaron haddam
Dialogue: Gentlemen. The conservative faction of border and western Republicans cannot approve this amendment, about which we harbor grave doubts, if a peace offer is being held hostage to its success. Joining with our Democratic colleagues, I second the motion to postpone.

Speaker: robert latham
Dialogue: Quick, man! Quick!

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: This is precisely what Mr. Wood wishes me to respond to?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Give this to Mr. Ashley.

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: I feel, um, I have to say, Mr. Lincoln, that this -  Could you please just step outside?!

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: Making false representation to Congress is, it's, um -

Speaker: john nicolay
Dialogue: It's, it's -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Impeachable. I've made no false representation.

Speaker: john hay
Dialogue: But there are -

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Give me the note, Johnnie.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: From the President:

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: "So far as I know-"?! That means nothing! Are there commissioners from the South or aren't there?!

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: The President has answered you, sir! Your peace offer is a fiction!

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: That is not a denial, it is a lawyer's dodge!

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Mr. Haddam? Is your faction satisfied?

Speaker: aaron haddam
Dialogue: The conservative Republican faction's satisfied, and we thank Mr. Lincoln. I move to table Mr. Wood's motion.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: Tabled!

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Speaker Colfax, I order the main question.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: A motion has been made to bring the bill for the Thirteenth Amendment to a vote. Do I hear a second?

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: So moved, so ordered. The Clerk will now -  Quiet please.

Speaker: augustus benjamin
Dialogue: Nay!

Speaker: arthur bentleigh
Dialogue: Nay!

Speaker: john ellis
Dialogue: Aye!

Speaker: democratic senator
Dialogue: What?! Shameful!

Speaker: walter appleton
Dialogue: I vote no!

Speaker: josiah burton
Dialogue: Beanpole Burton is pleased to vote yea!

Speaker: nehemiah cleary
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Mr. Martinson has delegated me to say he is indisposed and he abstains.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Also indisposed, also abstaining.

Speaker: harold hollister
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: william hutton
Dialogue: William Hutton, remembering at this moment his beloved brother, Fredrick, votes against the amendment.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Webster Allen votes no.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Webster Allen, Illinois, Democrat, votes...no.

Speaker: george yeaman
Dialogue: I said aye, Mr. McPherson. AYE!!!

Speaker: fernando wood
Dialogue: TRAITOR! TRAITOR!

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: Order!

Speaker: clay hawkins
Dialogue: Goddamn it, I'm voting yes.

Speaker: edwin leclerk
Dialogue: No.  Oh to hell with it, shoot me dead too. Yes!

Speaker: alexander coffroth
Dialogue: I. Vote. Yes.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: James Brooks...nay.

Speaker: meyer straus
Dialogue: Nay.

Speaker: joseph marstern
Dialogue: Nay.

Speaker: howard guilefoyle
Dialogue: Yea.

Speaker: avon hanready
Dialogue: Nay.

Speaker: rufus warren
Dialogue: Yea.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: Mr. Clerk, please call my name, I want to cast a vote.

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: I object! The Speaker doesn't vote!

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: The Speaker may vote if he so chooses.

Speaker: george pendleton
Dialogue: It is highly unusual, sir -

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: This isn't usual, Mr. Pendleton, this is history.

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: Aye, of course.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: The bill, Mr. McPherson, may I...?

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: I'll return it in the morning. Creased, but unharmed.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: A gift for you.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: I wish you'd been present.

Speaker: lydia smith
Dialogue: I wish I'd been.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: It was a spectacle.

Speaker: lydia smith
Dialogue: You can't bring your housekeeper to the House. I won't give them gossip.  This is enough. This is... It's more than enough for now.

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: Read it to me again, my love.

Speaker: lydia smith
Dialogue: "PROPOSED -"

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: And adopted.

Speaker: lydia smith
Dialogue: Adopted. "An Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. Section One: Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction."

Speaker: thaddeus stevens
Dialogue: SECTION TWO:

Speaker: lydia smith
Dialogue: "Congress shall have power to enforce this amendment by appropriate legislation."

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: Let me be blunt. Will the southern states resume their former position in the Union speedily enough to enable us to block ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I'd like peace immediately.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: Yes, and...?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I'd like your states restored to their practical relations to the Union immediately.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: If this could be given me in writing, as Vice President of the Confederacy, I'd bring that document with celerity to Jefferson Davis.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: Surrender and we can discuss reconstruction.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: Surrender won't be thought of unless you've assured us, in writing, that we'll be readmitted in time to block this amendment.

Speaker: seward
Dialogue: You'll not be conquered people, Mr. Hunter. You will be citizens, returned to the laws and the guarantees of rights of the Constitution.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: Which now extinguishes slavery. And with it our economy. All our laws will be determined by a Congress of vengeful Yankees, all our rights'll be subject to a Supreme Court benched by Black Republican radicals. All our traditions will be obliterated. We won't know ourselves anymore.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: We ain't here to discuss reconstruction, we have no legal basis for that discussion. But I don't want to deal falsely. The Northern states'll ratify, most of `em. As I figure, it remains for two of the Southern states to do the same, even after all are readmitted. And I been working on that.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: Tennessee and Louisiana.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Arkansas too, most likely. It'll be ratified. Slavery, sir, it's done.

Speaker: alexander stephens
Dialogue: How've you held your Union together? Through democracy? How many hundreds of thousands have died during your administration? Your Union, sir, is bonded in cannonfire and death.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: It may be you're right. But say all we done is show the world that democracy isn't chaos, that there is a great invisible strength in a people's union? Say we've shown that a people can endure awful sacrifice and yet cohere? Mightn't that save at least the idea of democracy, to aspire to? Eventually, to become worthy of? At all rates, whatever may be proven by blood and sacrifice must've been proved by now. Shall we stop this bleeding?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Once he surrenders, send his boys back to their homes, their farms, their shops.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: Yes sir, as we discussed.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Liberality all around. No punishment. I don't want that. And the leaders - Jeff and the rest of `em - if they escape, leave the country while my back's turned, that wouldn't upset me none.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: By outward appearance, you're ten years older than you were a year ago.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Some weariness has bit at my bones.  I never seen the like of it before. What I seen today. Never seen the like of it before.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: You always knew that, what this was going to be. Intimate, and ugly. You must've needed to see it close when you decided to come down here.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: We've made it possible for one another to do terrible things.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: And we've won the war. Now you have to lead us out of it.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You've an itch to travel?

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I'd like that. To the West by rail.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Overseas.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: The Holy Land.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Awfully pious for a man who takes his wife out buggy-riding on Good Friday.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Jerusalem. Where David and Solomon walked. I dream of walking in that ancient city.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: All anyone will remember of me is I was crazy and I ruined your happiness.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Anyone thinks that doesn't understand, Molly.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: When they look at you, at what it cost to live at the heart of this, they'll wonder at it. They'll wonder at you. They should. But they should also look at the wretched woman by your side, if they want to understand what this was truly like. For an ordinary person. For anyone other than you.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: We must try to be happier. We must. Both of us. We've been so miserable for so long.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: I did say some colored men, the intelligent, the educated, and veterans, I qualified it.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Mr. Stevens is furious, he wants to know why you qualified it -

Speaker: schuyler colfax
Dialogue: No one heard the intelligent or the educated part. All they heard was the first time any president has ever made mention of Negro voting.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Still, I wish I'd mentioned it in a better speech.

Speaker: james ashley
Dialogue: Mr. Stevens also wants to know why you didn't make a better speech.

Speaker: john nicolay
Dialogue: Mrs. Lincoln's waiting in the carriage. She wants me to remind you of the hour, and that you'll have to pick up Miss Harris and Major Rathbone.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Am I in trouble?

Speaker: william slade
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Slade.

Speaker: leonard grover
Dialogue: The President has been shot.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Now he belongs to the ages.

Speaker: lincoln
Dialogue: Yet, if God wills that it continue until all the wealth piled by the bondman's two hundred and fifty years of unrequited toil shall be sunk, and until every drop of blood drawn with the lash shall be paid by another drawn with the sword, as was said three thousand years ago, so still it must be said "the judgments of the Lord are true and righteous altogether."
